hints_html:
The Jacobian matrix is the matrix of all the first-order partial derivatives.

Let f(x,y) and g(x,y) be the right hand side of x’ and y’, respectively. Then the Jacobian matrix is

:J = \left(\begin{array}{cc} f_x & f_y \\ g_x & g_y \end{array}\right)
hints_latex:
The Jacobian matrix is the matrix of all the first-order partial
derivatives.

Let \emph{f(x,y)} and \emph{g(x,y)} be the right hand side of x' and y',
respectively. Then the Jacobian matrix is

:J = \textbackslash{}left(\textbackslash{}begin\{array\}\{cc\} f\_x \&
f\_y \textbackslash{}\textbackslash{} g\_x \& g\_y
\textbackslash{}end\{array\}\textbackslash{}right)
hints_raw:
The Jacobian matrix is the matrix of all the first-order partial derivatives.
Let ''f(x,y)'' and ''g(x,y)'' be the right hand side of x' and y', respectively. Then the Jacobian matrix is

:<math>J = \left(\begin{array}{cc}
f_x & f_y \\ g_x & g_y
\end{array}\right)
question: 7 (b)
sols_html:
We will denote \(f(x,y) = \frac{dx}{dt}(x,y) = x(2 - x - y)\) and \(g(x,y) = \frac{dy}{dt}(x,y) = y(1-x)\). Then the Jacobian matrix at at point \((x,y)\) is

\[\begin{aligned} J(x,y) = \left(\begin{array}{cc} f_x(x,y) & f_y(x,y) \\ g_x(x,y) & g_y(x,y) \end{array}\right) = \left(\begin{array}{cc} 2 - 2x - y & -x \\ -y & 1-x \end{array}\right).\end{aligned}\]
statement_html:
Consider the system of equations

\[\begin{aligned} x' &= x(2-x-y) \\ y' &= y(1-x)\end{aligned}\]

(b) Find the Jacobian matrix of the system.
statement_raw:
Consider the system of equations

:<math>
\begin{align}
x' &= x(2-x-y) \\
y' &= y(1-x)
\end{align}
</math>

'''(b)''' Find the Jacobian matrix of the system.
